paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: Can intratumoral delivery of SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines create an interferon-rich inflammatory state that improves sensitivity to anti-PD-L1 immune checkpoint therapy in tumors?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse efficacy cohort (combination therapy)
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Pooled across repeat experiments testing the combination of intratumoral mRNA vaccine with anti-PD-L1 therapy in multiple murine tumor models.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse control cohort (monotherapies and vehicle)
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Pooled across matched control groups receiving vaccine-only treatment, ICI-only treatment, or vehicle control.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human retrospective metastatic cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Retrospective cohort of metastatic patients receiving ICI treatment, analyzed by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human vaccination subgroups
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subgroup analysis comparing outcomes between patients with prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination and those without, within the metastatic cohort receiving ICI.

major_limitations: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients, introducing heterogeneity.
Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation.
Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.
Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.
The study does not include prospective randomized clinical trial data to validate clinical protocols.
